It’s a bad idea to yank a charging cable. Even though the rubber sleeve is stretchable, the copper wire inside is not as much. If you yank a cable often enough, the wire may break inside and would lose connectivity intermittently. If the cable is a high wattage power cable, the invisible internal breakage may even cause electric arcing and start a fire. Always pull by grabbing the plug, never yank by the cable!

The momentum of the circular wave will be transferred down the length of the whip. As the wave moves down the tapered whip the wave become lighter and lighter the mass of the wave becomes less and less.

To maintain the original momentum the reduced mass must move faster and faster.

What if you had a wheel that could maintain its structure; but the wheel could drop some of its mass as it rolled. If the mass is dropped at the bottom of the rolling wheel the dropped mass would not be moving. Sense the dropped mass is not moving its absence from the wheel would not carry away momentum. It's all about the explosive dissolution of the waveform created and amplified by the initial swing. You're transmitting that initial force waveform into a smaller and smaller area of the whip body to accelerate and amplify it. The cracker at the end is dramatically smaller and fan shaped specifically to dump all the energy of the waveform at the end of the swing, accelerating the tip past the sound barrier and causing the sonic boom crack we've all come to expect. Or so it would seem...

I would suggest that the last acceleration and amplification of the waveform is actually being caused by the phase change between the energy of the swing being transmitted by the solid matter of the whip fibers into the much-less-dense fluid of the air around it. That last jump in energy at the end accelerates the actual air molecules around that last section of the whip so fast that they cause explosive friction against the static air around them. So in essence, it's not the actual whip that's cracking, it's the air at the end of the whip cracking against itself.

So I guess a whip is literally a form of energy-amplifying fan...since you're literally using it's properties to move tiny amounts of air molecules so fast that they can't get out of the way of each other. The fact that the boom actually happens in the air is also why the whip inself stays intact afterwards. If the waveform collapsed any sooner, you'd likely explode the end of the whip every time you used it.

Funny to imagine what a whip would do if it were uses in other more or less dense atmospheres or fluids. If you tried to use it in a heavy atmosphere, would the whip actually crack you back? 🤔

I agree that the hypersonic movement is caused by the acceleration of the tip and that the acceleration is caused by conservation of momentum and the decreasing diameter (or, more exactly, mass density) of the whip along its length toward the tip. But I think the acceleration is still high even if the diameter or density is constant along the length of the whip. This is because of the following fact.

At any time during whipping, we can devide the whip into two parts the upper part (near the tip) and the lower part (near the hand). The main momentum is generated by only the upper part because the lower part is almost stationary during whipping. Due to the law of conservation of momentum, the upper part has to speed up because the length (and mass) is decreasing during whipping. The rate of relative decrease of mass of upper part is, in fact, accelerating toward the end of the whipping process, which results in accelerating rate of relative increase of the speed.

I once got half credit on a test question because I drew a chess board, and pieces. It was a physics question about movement, and my answer was "The queen can only move on the diagonals"

I know the queen can do more moves than that, but the partial credit was given, because while I forgot the formula to the problem, I knew the solution was a combination of 2 answers given, where one was correct, and one was imaginary.

However, I also know imaginary numbers can be represented by real numbers, and therefor, the queen can only move on the diagonals was my way of expressing that I knew I needed a number + some y'cos(theta) as the whole answer.

I saved the problem for last, and just sketched that out and wrote that answer when I couldn't remember how to set up the equation, I didn't expect credit, I didn't expect anyone to understand.

When I showed my friend, they were outraged I was given credit, and I tried to explain why, and they just told me I was given credit because the teacher liked me.

This video makes me think about how sometimes it isn't what we understand, but it is what we see, and how we use what we see to describe the intricacies of life.

Just wanna set the record straight for Scientific Journal purposes: The tip of the bullwhip is NOT breaking the Sound BARRIER...it is in Fact, breaking the Air Pressure/Density BARRIER....which is a Real Physical Barrier.

It is a simple matter of Cause and Effect.
Cause: object pushes hard against the Air Barrier with sufficient Speed (action of the bullwhip)
Effect: a cracking sound is produced from the expanding and collapsing of the Air Pressure and Density Barrier around said object.

You will also notice small white Condensation Clouds formed near the moment of the Air Barrier being broken. This is from compression of Air near the leading edge of the bullwhip tassle, and occurs just as a small pocket of Air expands and collapses around the bullwhip tassle.

The physical action of the expansion and quick collapse of Air near the leading edge of the bullwhip tassle is what produces the Sound. The effect of the action of Breaking the Air Barrier.

If you do not Break the Air Barrier FIRST .... there will never be the accompanying Sound of Air expanding and collapsing rapidly around the tassle..which is the cracking Sound produced, from breaking the Air Barrier. Thanks.

Just wanted people to have Clarification on the actual Physics of what's happening, instead of people having the Misconception that the bullwhip tassle somehow broke a Sound Barrier.

You mentioned that there was a possibility that the shockwave could drive the end of the whip, which I believe you to actually be correct. In the clips I noticed that as soon as the sound barrier is broken and the wave has formed, immediately after forming the shockwave seems to have the whips tip within the centerline of the wave. Almost as though the tail end of the wave is the portion of the shockwave that carries the force of the shockwave. This seems to be something I’ve also noticed in videos with sonic booms from volcanic eruptions, to even the Beirut blast. When slowed down, the glass from the Beirut blast and the force from a video of a volcanic eruption filmed on a boat, isn’t felt immediately upon the initial connection of the sound wave. It seems as though the force is just milliseconds behind the blast. When watching your video it makes sense that the force that’s so destructive in these large scale real events, is what could possibly be driving the whips tip to such extreme forces.

Very clever and interesting. At 8:12 you say that it looks like the tip of the whip is getting pulled along behind the shock wave. I think rather that the velocity of the whip tip has a) slowed because it hits itself (actualizing and losing its potential energy), and b) is slower than the speed of sound. Thus, the sound wave is "out-running" the tip and it appears as though the tip is chasing the wave.

Also, the probable reason that the knot disallows the pop is that it has changed the flow of the taper and the bulk at the tip then acts like a bobble-head bouncing around and cannot strike the smallest tapered piece, since it's bulk prevents it from slamming into it. The speed increases down the length of the taper until the larger mass at the end "slowly" catches up and deadens the velocity increase, preventing the breaking of the sound barrier, thus disabling the potential snap. VERY clever and educated experiment!

If you note with the popper the strands tighten before breaking the sound barrier. They don't without it. I think the popper causes the wave to more equally travel along the strands on the end of the whip. They tighten as the approach the sound barrier in speed, then come apart after breaking it due to the force needed to break it.

I have an intuitive theory on this one. The reason it snaps before the end of the tip is because it has already passed the sound barrier... At the moment of snap, the end gets a lot of kinetic energy, but not from the wave coming up the rope. It snaps before the wave reaches it. Where does it get the kinetic energy from? Because at that same moment it goes super sonic, the sound waves it's emitting get faster than the waves before. The epicenter of the current wave is outside the past wave, causing the two waves to collide and push each other. So the air moves together with those waves at the speed of sound. That air movement totally removes air friction for rope and gives it a lot more kinetic energy. All tho I'm not sure if it gives... The rope it self is traveling the same speed as air- supersonic. So maybe it only removes air friction for the rope? Many of you say what air friction is too weak, it doesn't do that much... But when it comes to small masses and huge speeds, it can have a big role.

Destin, those inlet cones travel back into the nacelle at speeds above 1.4 Mach and the shockwave is directed through a series of pipes and reintroduced behind the engine and used as thrust. For those wondering the diff between the A-12 and the SR-71...they performed the same mission -- strategic reconnaissance.  The primary difference was the A-12 was a single-seat plane operated by the CIA, while the SR-71 was a 2 seater (pilot in front, radar systems officer in a separate cockpit behind him) operated bu the US Air Force.  They had VERY similar performance...the lack of a 2nd crewman and his associated gear giving the A-12 marginally better speed and altitude performance.

the trick to the SR71 was that spike on the front, that nifty-keen comicbook spaceship lookin' leading edge, and the cones on the engines, basically what it was doing is it was making the compression wave up at the leading edge of the aircraft (the sonic boom) happen on a really focused path and directing it right back into the engines to feed energy into the compression stage of the process.
so right when the plane hits the sound barrier and starts pumping energy into the air in front of it trying to push the whole mass instead of flowing through it what it ends up doing is pushing all that wasted energy right back into it's engines (most of it anyways, even if they got it all perfect the air would still manage to transfer some energy to the stuff around it). the plane actually burns less fuel after getting comfortably supersonic than at its minimum airspeed.
so, with all that it sounds like the plane can go pretty much as fast as it wants right? or at least as fast as the engines can push stuff out the back...welll, there's a bit of a problem with that: *heat*: that spike and that neat leading edge are pushing through an absurd amount of friction and compression which in turn deposits and absurd amount of heat, the plane can pretty much go as fast as it wants right up until it melts it's own face off.
...I wonder how fast we could get a modernised sr71 derivative going these days, not actually sure if we have anything all that much better for materials than what they were using back then, might have a bit better understanding of how to disperse heat out of the critical parts though.

I really enjoyed watching this.
When I was a child, I took a stick and some fishing line and made a rudimentary whip.
I never had the video footage to back it up, but always thought that the shockwave formed when the momentum of the spiraling line would reach the end of the line, causing the forward momentum of the tip to be greatly accelerated as it reverses direction.
As seen in this experiment, the momentum being unable to continue propagation is causing a sudden immense acceleration of the tip as it is drawn towards the opposite direction of motion.
This would increase the speed traveling as the radius of the wave propagation is getting much much smaller than the original wave created from the wrist movement. As discussed, conservation of momentum of this wavelength (getting smaller and smaller towards the tip) ends up being unable to continue propagating as a solid wave (the whip), which allows the momentum to transfer to the surrounding air as the tip of the whip is reversing direction (the sudden and drastic hyper-acceleration into supersonic speeds - the crack)
Perhaps this experiment could be developed further by creating known wavelengths of initial energy inputs, coupled with varying speeds of this initial wavelength. Maybe we could see what whip cracks at mach 2, 3 or even 4 would look like!

I cannot imagine why the presenter previously thought the crack occurred at the moment of full extension of the whip. That's when the movement of the tip of the whip is checked so if the crack has not happened by then it is not going to happen at all. The crack would have to happen while some part of the whip is in motion and accelerating to and through the speed of sound.

That is, if the cause of the crack is something exceeding the speed of sound as the scientists tell us it is. It's hard for a layman like myself to form an impression of just how far into the movement of the whip some part of it reaches and then exceeds the speed of sound. This would certainly vary with different whips and the individual "action" of different whipsters.

Further acceleration after the sound barrier has been crossed would not generate any further crack (or extend the audible duration of the crack) even though the motion is above the speed of sound. One would expect the tip of the whip to continue accelerating after the crack but the critical moment has passed and further acceleration would happen silently, or nearly so.

Technically speaking, the whip and the jet are not breaking the sound barrier.  They are breaking the air barrier, and thats why condensation clouds form just before the air collapses and makes a sound.  So in science we call this "wind pops". Nothing to do with breaking a "sound barrier".  EVERYTHING to do with the air barrier.  Jus sayin....without getting scientific and stuff.

Do you think it is possible that when we are seeing the tip of the wip while it is being pulled along and not under tension is simply a view of it riding in the transonic zone similar to a more rigid projectile like a bullet. It has a definite begining and end and its curiouse to me that the tip is not pulled tight as is comes on screen making me think that it is tight at the begining of the stroke (an assumption but a good one i believe) then moves into the zone prior to coming on screen. Is it posible then that we are seeing it leave the zone, break the barrier and then return to the zone. When the tip is taught and moving above the sound barrier it should be in a area of even pressure where the front and back of the tip (just the tip not the wip) are simply moving through air with a stable pressure due to no longer having to contend with the forces of the zone hence keeping it in the middle of the shockwave until the drag coeficient is high enough to overcome the pressure behind the tip or another outside force slows it to somewhere below mach 1.2 down to mach .8 or soo. This may explain why we see the tip moving inside of a turbulent area directly prior to the formation of the shock wave and another area of turbulence directly after. Another theory I have is that the tip is being partially drug by the wip and partially pushed along because of the high pressure region created behind it due to the pressure farther down its path being reduced by the shockwave. This sould only be in play after the tip speed falls below the zone and the sound begins to outrun it.

There are two distinctly different mechanisms occurring.    The first as you have stated is the energy transport by the wave.     It is a rope attached at one end (node at the stationary hand after the energy was put in) and the wave travels the length of the whip up to the last moments .     Once the wave gets near the tip, the mechanism changes.    Instead of a long traveling wave, the mechanism becomes chaotic because the masses of the tip section and the section just before it are harmonic oscillators with each other.  It becomes a two pendulum problem when the wave nears the end of the whip since the mass of the string on one side of the whip approaches the mass at the end of the whip.  Under these conditions, there will be a momentum exchange between the two harmonic oscillators.     Normally it would be chaotic but the the driving mass of the length of the whip still exists so this condition of harmonic oscillation of the tip and the near tip string are, in effect, forced.    This yields the result in a two pendulum system where the heavier end of the pendulum is not moving very fast but the second pendulum has had the momentum nearly all transferred to is resulting in a very high velocity for one oscillation.    Of course this is the place for the Lagrangian equations of motion for the two pendulum system (2DOF) to explain the high tip velocity .

The tip acceleration I would guess is because there is no more whip to transfer energy to. Looking at the loop in the whip that the wave creates, the momentum is gradually increasing along the next whip segments. Once it gets to the tip, there should be a breaking point where the whole tip is moving at the same speed as the base of the wave and when the wave continues to get shorter, that energy of multiple segments from the wave transfers as a higher velocity at the tip, a velocity much higher than the base wave velocity. I believe something like this could also explain why the tip doesn't slow down and breaks the sound barrier despite it having more mass than the previous sections of the whip.
Perhaps this rapid transference "consumes" the wave energy so fast that the wave never gets completed at the whip end just before the tip, explaining why in the video it looks like the whip cracks before the loop is completely unraveled; it seems that there is a point where the loop freezes just before the tip making an "S" shape 8:14

You already knew the basics of how the whip works - it is analogous to a tapered line for matching impedance in radio electronics. Interestingly, a classic Tesla Coil incorporates the same phenomenon - the decreasing capacitance to ground along the length of the secondary is a part of the voltage rise at resonance.

Man this was an AWESOME episode. Totally geeking out. It's super rad when intuition is proven wrong by science. As a software engineer, I live for the moments when data proves me wrong and I learn something I didn't know.

The SR-71 required a refuel a few minutes after take-off. Due to the temperature of the aircraft skin during high-speed flight, they were required to use a wet wing without an integral bladder. This basically means that the wings are the fuel tank and no rubber or other type of material could be used to prevent leakage of the fuel from the wing. Also as a result of the temperature of the aircraft skin during high-speed flight, the joints between the titanium sheets were not directly abutted when the aircraft was cold. When the skin would heat up, the sheets would expand, sealing the inter-sheet cracks but not causing over-expansion and buckling. The design tolerances were very tight on this aspect as they needed the cracks to close as much as possible to reduce turbulence at the surface of the skin (and increase aerodynamic drag) but also prevent the aforementioned buckling.
The combination of the wet wing and the non-expanded sheets caused the SR-71 to leak fuel like a sieve prior to takeoff. Basically, the sequence would be something like:
* Fuel the aircraft at the end of the runway with engines running.
* Immediately take off with fuel leaking at a high rate.
* Perform a sufficient number of high speed passes to heat up the skin and close the cracks.
* Receive in-air refueling and proceed to mission.

The SR-71 is an absolutely crazy aircraft and was purpose built for high altitude reconnaissance at ultra high speed. It is still not known what the actual maximum speed of the aircraft is as that is still classified information.

Hey Destin, I have a very strange phenomenon to ask you about...
While eating yummy caramel corn, I was biting some of the pieces in half. After biting one, a second or two later it exploded a bit sending tiny shards of caramel crumbs everywhere.. I did it again and it kept happening. (I was biting them to avoid some of the big hard kernel pieces.)

I think it was happening because my bite compresses the popcorn a bit, and then it expands back to shape causing the caramel to pop.. but then I realized that makes no sense... because the hard caramel should've been broken already once I bit into it, and if the popcorn was just returning to it's original size and shape... how could that generate enough force to crack and launch the caramel shards off... also sometimes the delay was several seconds!
I couldn't figure this out and thought.. "Hmm, there must be something neat happening here. I know of just the guy to figure it out!"
Anyway, I hope you see this and try it out or think about it, I don't dream you'd actually make a video about it, but I figured I'd try to reach out!

To anyone reading, feel free to try it out and let me know what you think! Again, I had Werthers Original brand Caramel corn, just the original plain kind, no added stuff like nuts or anything and I was just biting them in half. I hope to figure this neat little mystery out!

Anyways, Destin I've always been a huge fan, and as you can tell, you often pop into my mind when I make neat discoveries and I try to imagine how Destin would approach solving the problem I find myself faced with. You've inspired me to learn and I hope to pass that on. Thanks! As someone with lung cancer and doesn't get out much, science and learning mean a lot to me! the reason the tips appear to come together is because as they approach the sound barrier, a cone is formed, and as such they come closer to each other. the reason the shockwave seems to drag the tip forward is beacause when the barrier is breached a miniature vacuum is created and thus creates suction. this can happen for a millisecond, to seconds at a time but the result is the same. a vacuum, in the atmosphere of our planet, will create suction, as there is nothing there, and as the tip of the whip is the only thing currently moving at approximately the same speed, it will be pulled in first. the air will follow shortly.

The vector of tranferred conservation inertia is linear, linear to x axis which means somewhere (obviously end of a tip of rope) it has to end, spend that all conserved energy somehow, but the tip is really small so the velocity of it will be very fast.

Its interesting because most of conservative inertia, especially circular inertia cannot be ended or be finite, because momentum keeps ongoing infinite roop, therefore has to transfer the conservation other dimension, needing one more dimension. There are a few things i wish you would have done to TRULY test whats going on when the tip breaks the sound barrier. Those are to test if the same things happen when you use a TOWEL as a whip. Using a towel as a whip is why i could have told you before hand that the flared ends on the whip WERE NOT THE CAUSE of the crack sound, because a towel will do the same thing and its solid, and will even having its tip ripped after breaking the sound barrier a few times and in my experiences will become less as effective. Also, i believe that the whip being tapered also DOES NOT have anything to do with it speeding up as a towel is not tapered either. So there are two problems with your theories. So what i purpose is that as the TIP of either a whip or a towel is being pulled behind the rest of it, when the whip/towel reaches its length limit, the sudden stop in forward momentum causes the whip/towel to then be jerked back on itself, this causes the section that is being pulled along at the tip to suddenly and VERY quickly increase in speed for just a millisecond in order to catch up with the rest of it. As we can see in the video the whip's momentum even cause it to bounce itself back towards the user even when they are not physically pulling the whip back themselves. Just the way i think about it, is how when a jet plane or a car makes a fast and sudden turn at high speed it creates a sudden increase in G forces in one direcrion, which can cause extra movement that be felt more towards the rear of the vehicle and why some people will get car sick riding in the rear but not the front. But anyways, This quick and violent increase in speed causes the tip of both a whip and a towel to get that last little bit of speed it needs in order to break the sound barrier. Up until that time the entire length of the whip is moving at relatively the same speed and has nothing to do with it being tapered or not or having those little flared ends on it or not, but rather has MUCH more to do with the LENGTH of the overall whip and the WEIGHT of the tip. Where a whip will have the knots at the end and even those "tassels" to add a small ammount of weight just as in how a towel with a wet tip to add a small ammount of weight will work better as well. The taper is only a partial factor in the acceleration of the end of the whip. It has more to do with the the conservation of momentum. At the start of the stroke he entire mass of the whip is moving forward. As each “segment” curves around, its forward motion is halted and the momentum is transferred to the remaining portion of the whip that is still moving. From start to finish, the momentum of the mass of the entire whip is transferred to the mass of the very tip. As mass of moving portion of the whip decreases, speed increases. This is why you can get the same effect with a charging cable (or a rope) that is not tapered. It is the same reason why cars that are engineered to have parts fly off in a collision are safer for the occupants of the car, as more of the total momentum is transferred to the pieces that come off, rather than the occupants bodies.

There were a lot of things we couldn't do in an SR-71, but we were the fastest guys on the block and loved reminding our fellow aviators of this fact. People often asked us if, because of this fact, it was fun to fly the jet. Fun would not be the first word I would use to describe flying this plane. Intense, maybe. Even cerebral. But there was one day in our Sled experience when we would have to say that it was pure fun to be the fastest guys out there, at least for a moment.

It occurred when Walt and I were flying our final training sortie. We needed 100 hours in the jet to complete our training and attain Mission Ready status. Somewhere over Colorado we had passed the century mark. We had made the turn in Arizona and the jet was performing flawlessly. My gauges were wired in the front seat and we were starting to feel pretty good about ourselves, not only because we would soon be flying real missions but because we had gained a great deal of confidence in the plane in the past ten months. Ripping across the barren deserts 80,000 feet below us, I could already see the coast of California from the Arizona border. I was, finally, after many humbling months of simulators and study, ahead of the jet.

I was beginning to feel a bit sorry for Walter in the back seat. There he was, with no really good view of the incredible sights before us, tasked with monitoring four different radios. This was good practice for him for when we began flying real missions, when a priority transmission from headquarters could be vital. It had been difficult, too, for me to relinquish control of the radios, as during my entire flying career I had controlled my own transmissions. But it was part of the division of duties in this plane and I had adjusted to it. I still insisted on talking on the radio while we were on the ground, however. Walt was so good at many things, but he couldn't match my expertise at sounding smooth on the radios, a skill that had been honed sharply with years in fighter squadrons where the slightest radio miscue was grounds for beheading. He understood that and allowed me that luxury.

Just to get a sense of what Walt had to contend with, I pulled the radio toggle switches and monitored the frequencies along with him. The predominant radio chatter was from Los Angeles Center, far below us, controlling daily traffic in their sector. While they had us on their scope (albeit briefly), we were in uncontrolled airspace and normally would not talk to them unless we needed to descend into their airspace.

We listened as the shaky voice of a lone Cessna pilot asked Center for a readout of his ground speed. Center replied: "November Charlie 175, I'm showing you at ninety knots on the ground."

Now the thing to understand about Center controllers, was that whether they were talking to a rookie pilot in a Cessna, or to Air Force One, they always spoke in the exact same, calm, deep, professional, tone that made one feel important. I referred to it as the " Houston Center voice." I have always felt that after years of seeing documentaries on this country's space program and listening to the calm and distinct voice of the Houston controllers, that all other controllers since then wanted to sound like that, and that they basically did. And it didn't matter what sector of the country we would be flying in, it always seemed like the same guy was talking. Over the years that tone of voice had become somewhat of a comforting sound to pilots everywhere. Conversely, over the years, pilots always wanted to ensure that, when transmitting, they sounded like Chuck Yeager, or at least like John Wayne. Better to die than sound bad on the radios.

Just moments after the Cessna's inquiry, a Twin Beech piped up on frequency, in a rather superior tone, asking for his ground speed. "I have you at one hundred and twenty-five knots of ground speed." Boy, I thought, the Beechcraft really must think he is dazzling his Cessna brethren. Then out of the blue, a navy F-18 pilot out of NAS Lemoore came up on frequency. You knew right away it was a Navy jock because he sounded very cool on the radios. "Center, Dusty 52 ground speed check". Before Center could reply, I'm thinking to myself, hey, Dusty 52 has a ground speed indicator in that million-dollar cockpit, so why is he asking Center for a readout? Then I got it, ol' Dusty here is making sure that every bug smasher from Mount Whitney to the Mojave knows what true speed is. He's the fastest dude in the valley today, and he just wants everyone to know how much fun he is having in his new Hornet. And the reply, always with that same, calm, voice, with more distinct alliteration than emotion: "Dusty 52, Center, we have you at 620 on the ground."

And I thought to myself, is this a ripe situation, or what? As my hand instinctively reached for the mic button, I had to remind myself that Walt was in control of the radios. Still, I thought, it must be done - in mere seconds we'll be out of the sector and the opportunity will be lost. That Hornet must die, and die now. I thought about all of our Sim training and how important it was that we developed well as a crew and knew that to jump in on the radios now would destroy the integrity of all that we had worked toward becoming. I was torn.

Somewhere, 13 miles above Arizona, there was a pilot screaming inside his space helmet. Then, I heard it. The click of the mic button from the back seat. That was the very moment that I knew Walter and I had become a crew. Very professionally, and with no emotion, Walter spoke: "Los Angeles Center, Aspen 20, can you give us a ground speed check?" There was no hesitation, and the replay came as if was an everyday request. "Aspen 20, I show you at one thousand eight hundred and forty-two knots, across the ground."

I think it was the forty-two knots that I liked the best, so accurate and proud was Center to deliver that information without hesitation, and you just knew he was smiling. But the precise point at which I knew that Walt and I were going to be really good friends for a long time was when he keyed the mic once again to say, in his most fighter-pilot-like voice: "Ah, Center, much thanks, we're showing closer to nineteen hundred on the money."

For a moment Walter was a god. And we finally heard a little crack in the armor of the Houston Center voice, when L.A.came back with, "Roger that Aspen, Your equipment is probably more accurate than ours. You boys have a good one."

It all had lasted for just moments, but in that short, memorable sprint across the southwest, the Navy had been flamed, all mortal airplanes on freq were forced to bow before the King of Speed, and more importantly, Walter and I had crossed the threshold of being a crew. A fine day's work. We never heard another transmission on that frequency all the way to the coast.

For just one day, it truly was fun being the fastest guys out there.

That pulling force of the tip of the whip, is the wave reaching the end of the medium and trying to continue to the next available medium, the air; due to air characteristics, part of the momentum is transferred into the air and other part is bounced back into the whip, it appears to look like that force happens before the momentum gets to the tip but you have to remember that waves have length, and the arrow in the video points to around the middle of the wave length as it moves through the whip while the very start of the wave length is ahead of it, in telecommunications that phenomenon is the base of the VSWR, with it we can measure how a signal (wave) traverse a medium and also see signal drops due to change of medium (smashed cable or bad conector)

To me, it didn't look like the tip was being dragged along behind the shockwave. It looked like the tip was pushing the shockwave along - much like the waves created if you quickly drag your hand through water. Perhaps it's sheer ignorance on my part, since I certainly can't claim to be a major science nerd or anything, but it seems logical enough that, at a certain rate of speed, the drag against the tip would become so great that the tip would begin physically displacing air rather than passing through it - sort of like holding your hand, palm open, out of a car window when traveling down the freeway. Of course, if the whip operates the same way with a pointed (i.e. - not threaded or splayed) tip, that would about wrap up that argument, since at that point the aerodynamics should (in my case) prohibit any such displacement.

If I'm right, however, it stands to reason that the snapping sound corresponding to the shockwave would be the point at which the whip collides with the pseudo-solid wall of air pressure, no?

I can't help but feel like I'm just an idiot stumbling in the dark, thinking that maybe just some of this actually makes sense. If so, I dearly hope someone educates me on it, because I am immensely curious.

I'm also trying to wrap my head around the concept of interference drag, since that seems relevant here, but overall this is just a very fascinating subject to arise from a very mundane thing. Thanks for the thought-provoking video.

The strange movement of the tip of the whip is because most the energy concentrated in the whip itself get transferred into the surrounding air as an compression wave when the speed of the tip comes close to the speed of sound. The ait can't move fast enough to let the whip move freely. The speed of the air-wave and the speed of the tip equalize and after that the tip get "dragged along" in the low pressure region after the high pressure wave front. I think it happens even earlier but it can't be heard, because the air molecules can be moves fast enough so only a very low frequency sound is produced.
It would be interesting to hear how the wave is travelling trough the whip itself. Would it be possible to put a high speed microphone on the whip to record the reflections of the pressure-wave travelling inside of the whip?

So it is not the change in direction of the tip, it is the additive speed and transfer of mass from the larger sections to the smaller sections that cause the end of the whip to break the sound barrier.

It makes sense that the tail would break the sound barrier before reaching its end. After reaching the end it will not go faster. It accelerates because of its taper; as the energy wave moves to the end, heavier elements transfer to lighter elements, and due to the conservation of energy, the lighter elements move faster.
On the reverse, the energy is transferred to heavier elements and so it slows down. It is also very unlikely to get the tip to hit the speed of sound just as the wave reaches the end.

I read the tip breaks the speed of sound because the kinetic energy generated by the momentum is transfered through the whole section of the whip. And the farther away from the handle, the smaller the cross section of the whip becomes and the same kinetic energy is transfered through a smaller section. Thus, the conservation of momentum makes the tip go faster and faster to release the energy concentrated in the smallest segment, just like the water speeds up when you squeeze the hose (fluid dynamics y'all). So, the energy concentrating in the tip of the whip speeds it up in order to conserve the momentum and it achieves the speed of sound. I think the tip cracks before it gets fully stretched out because that's when it's crossing the top of the wave (like a sine wave), and that's when the acceleration reaches its peak, making that "unfolding" movement and breaking the speed of sound.

But, hey, I'm just a civil engineer. I can only go so far regarding fluid dynamics and dynamic mechanics.

These might help keep the tip in a specific region. It could also be the case, that the conservation of momentum in addition to a bit of tension could keep the speed of the tip right above the sound barrier, as it would stop experiencing transsonic drag and would therefore get slowed down a lot less.

Something interesting would be recreating this in a vacuum environment and analyzing the speed differences, as they may reveal info both in the changes of speed during the acceleratory phase and in the potential maximum speeds that may be achievable if the whip wasn't slowed down by both regular drag and skin-drag (especially the one at transsonic speeds).

The functioning part of the whip is getting smaller and smaller as it rolls out, thus following a similar pattern. The end is small and light because it's frayed, so it's easily propelled by the pinpointing of the unfolding whip.

Well when the shock forms, the drag coefficient goes up which makes the tip deaccelerate. So the whip tip reaches sonic speed briefly which is also the shock wave speed and then trails behind the shock. This is the answer to what you said about the tip being pulled behind which is not whats happening but the tip deaccelerating once the tip reaches sonic speed. In short the tip is not breaking the spund barrier(hence the bow shock) but kind of touching in layman terms

What always amazes me about these videos is how little we know about such common things. With science as advanced as it is it's easy to think we have everything figured out. We can send things into space and measure distances that we could never hope to travel yet the mechanisms behind things as common as dominos and whips remain a bit of a mystery.
When you watch a lot of science videos on youtube it's easy to get the feeling that everything has been tried and tested and we can do nothing but reap the benefits. As Destin often shows though, that's not true. There are still plenty of not-completely-explained phenomena in our world and plenty of room for experimentation and learning.

So idk if this is something y'all already thought of and it was obvious but I believe the reason the end of the whip trailed after the sound wave is because the wave was created by the end of the whip when the energy that was in the loop traveling down the whip reached the peak of the final loop before the end of the wip, the energy had no more room to make another loop since there was no more wip. Thus causing it to transfer that final bit of energy out like it had been explosively slingshotted out the remainder of whip so forcefully the whip didn't have time to finish the movement before the energy transferred to the end. Is it just me that thought 'How to weaponize the whip? Further weaponize, I mean'? Well, I did.

The mechanics of using conservation of momentum to increase speed can only be effectively used in non-continuous movement - i.e. I think its impossible to use it to transportation. So, to use this whip-mechanic to accelerate other things, this other thing needs to be small and light. So my first thought was 'BULLETS! We don't need guns anymore to kill people with bullets!'

So, I believe that throwing a small weight like a bullet because of air-dynamics through whip-mechanics is possible, and lethal. I believe such 'shot' would be similar to small guns.

Actually, I believe most of the challenge in producing such a weapon would be 1 - aiming it and 2 - transferring all the energy into forwarding force.

Is this because a USB cable is sheathed in a coating with a certain amount of rigidity that wants to stay together, so the wave moves along the length of the cable with the 'front' side having to move faster through a substance of low rigidity (air) to continue to move that wave through the 'back' side of the cable and it is the forces on each side of the cable that accelerated the tip?

Destin: Amazing video (as always). While I was watching it, it reminded me of a thing I was curious about as a child, and I think you'd be uniquely able to help answer it.

I love this video and I think it's worth pointing out the role that diversity plays in this fascinating story.

• Dustin is interesting because he's open-minded and interested in so many things. His interests are diverse.
• Pair Dustin (a white guy from the south) with another white guy from the south and you get an interesting view of supersonic bullets. Definitely cool but not exactly novel.
• Next add an asian lady with a very odd hobby (not trying to disparage!) and an engineering background to the mix, and they end up uncovering a novel question buried in a phenomenon that I (white male) assumed was settled physics.
• The research they are undertaking to answer this novel question, and add to the body of human knowledge, requires the expertise and equipment provided by a group of culturally diverse researchers, many of whom appear to be immigrants from other countries (perhaps even countries that are not necessarily US allies). Of course they are all homogeneous in their brilliance and desire to understand the world around them.
• Finally, the people of Alabama and the United States of America—a diverse group—paid into a system of taxes that enabled research like this to be carried out. The beauty of which is that this knowledge, shared with the people of Alabama, the US, and ultimately the world; can then be used by any curious person to further extend the bounds of human knowledge.

From the data, it seems pretty simple. The whip travels FASTER than the speed of sound, and thus produces the shockwave not at maximum extension/speed, but when its speed passes the speed of sound. So, using made up numbers, if the speed of sound is 1000kph, and the whip maxes out at 1500kph, that means the shockwave will occur earlier than max extension, as it accelerates up to 1500kph. The acceleration is so fast though, that it isn't physically far from the location it hits max speed, which is why it wasn't noticed until now due to technical limitations.

The whip end deflecting, if I had to guess, is just due to the power of the shockwave pulling it in a new direction.

Hi: I watched the first 7:30 of this, but I didn't need to watch quite that much to tell you what I think. Let's look at the whip as something like a spoke on a bicycle wheel. As the whip begins to extend further and further, you are creating something like a longer and longer spoke. Basically, when you have a turning wheel, the circumference of the wheel moves increasingly faster depending on the length of the radius (one of the spokes). As the radius increases, the circumference increases, and the speed at the circumference also increases. This is why when you have a good old-fashioned vinyl record playing on a record player, the speed near the center of the record can be rather slow, but the speed out at the very far edge of the record is much faster. Again, the greater the radius, the greater the circumferential speed. Now, getting back to the whip, the whip is like a bicycle spoke extending. It is also being moved slightly downward, which represents a slight turn (arc), or this is like a small turning of a bicycle wheel, maybe only a few degrees or so out of the 360 degrees that make one revolution. You really don't need to have the wheel turn very much, as long as you turn it a little bit. Anyway, as the whip begins to "unfurl" or extend outward, this increases the radius. The other movement is a slight downward movement imparted by the hand, which causes the "circumferential turning" (or what is like that). You have a downward movement that is multiplied more and more the further the whip extends outwards. That downward movement of the hand causes the "circumferential turning." I hope you can understand that what you're basically doing is creating a greater radius which is giving you a greater circumferential motion.

Let's think about the vinyl record again. If you impart motion near the center of the record with a movement of your wrist, that record near the center will be turning at a given speed, but out at the circumference it will be turning much, much faster. Now imagine that this "unfurling" whip is extending like the record to make it 12 feet or more in radius instead of just 12 inches or whatever. However, I am also logically compelled to ask, "Shouldn't the tip of the whip be slowing down and not speeding up?" Here is why (by example): When an ice skater is spinning really fast and next extends his or her arms outward, he or she slows down. On the other hand, by pulling in the arms, the skater speeds up, so the whip should be slowing its tip down as it extends further outward. Another idea I am thinking about is with the whip. Because this whip is flexing, you can send it one way and next pull back another way, so what you have is something like a combination of phenomena in effect. One phenomenon is like the bicycle wheel or the record I discussed, where things move faster further outwards away from the center. The other idea, though, is like this example: If you have two cars meeting at 60 miles an hour on the highway, when they pass each other, each has a relative speed of 120 miles per hour in relation to the other. Because you are sending the whip (tip) one way and next you can pull the handle back in the opposite direction, pretty soon you're going to have something like two different directions of motion, and if each is pretty fast, they are added together (like with the cars on the highway) to create a sudden summed up effect on the end area of the whip. The two different directions of motion meet in the area around the end of the tip.

I hope you enjoyed reading this. I think I'm going to get on to something else.

A compressible fluid going faster than its speed of sound will no longer act as a compressible fluid. As the end of the whip got to speed of sound, the shockwave formed an incompressible zone that has different sonic properties, which reflected the sound and produced a standing wave (“standing” in the frame of the shockwave). The end of the whip was caught in the anti-node of the standing wave.
A similar thing might occur with a raindrop falling on a pond. The reflection of sonic energy due to going from a compressible fluid (air) to incompressible (water) might result in the water bouncing.

You're in an unsteady, compressible flow regime, so you have to consider that the shock has rolled up from the accelerated whip prior to its arrival at the tip. In other words, the tip is being pulled along behind the shock, by the fluid created by unsteady (accelerated) motion of the whip. The tip may not cause the crack by accelerating through the sound barrier. Rather, the fluid in motion both creates the shock and drags the tip, perhaps also through the sound barrier, but not necessarily.

So something I'm noticing, is that the mechanics for this look very similar to what I had to study for my trebuchet project last year. All of the kinetic energy of the mass of the whip is transferred forward, building not unlike a wave in the ocean as it travels toward shore. In trebuchets, we try to time stall points, in order to maximize energy transfer efficiency. In a whip, every point along the whip, up to the last knot before the popper becomes itself a stall point, transferring nearly all of its initial energy into the remaining mass of the whip that is still moving.
However, the popper seems to act almost as its own mass, and its movement is remarkably similar to the sling on a trebuchet. The last knot stalls in place, and then actually moves backward just as the popper reaches its apex. The crack happens just before this, at the exact moment the last knot stalls.
This stall point, where the entire whip is frozen in space, looks very nearly like the last stall point on a trebuchet, where the weight, and the arm, have transferred all of their energy into the sling just as the projectile releases. Not only that, but since the whip is curled as it extends, this is also the moment where the popper is actually swinging in an arc around the last stall point.
As it tries to uncurl, part of the whip starts pulling perpendicular to the velocity direction of the tip of the popper, creating a point of centripetal force in the system as the popper "whips" around in an arc. Up to this point, the mass of the whip yet to uncurl was great enough that aerodynamic drag kept it traveling in a direction parallel to its length, meaning that the pull force was always directly along the length of the whip, parallel to the direction of travel. But at this point, where the mass of the whip yet to uncurl becomes low enough, the tip is able to swing out perpendicular to the direction of travel, creating centripetal force on the tip, equal to the total energy already in the system.
This would create a sudden, massive acceleration on the popper, pushing it beyond the sound barrier, and I'm curious how far. I believe it is because of this, that the crack happens just before full extension of the whip, and also why the popper appears to get pulled along with the wave. It is actually the other way around. The wave is pulled along with the popper.
The whole process then reverses, of course, and the whip curls back toward the thrower. Very interesting.

I'm not sure anyone else has mentioned this in the comments, and I am a layperson in these matters, but I believe the reason the "popper" is travelling with the shockwave might be related to compressibility and the reason prop driven aircraft can't go beyond Mach 1.

And just to make it interesting: The P-38 Lightning was one of the first aircraft to encounter compressibility on a repeatable and regular basis. The design lead for the P-38? Kelly Johnson, the engineer behind the Lockheed Skunk Works that designed and built the U-2 and A-12 series of aircraft.

How's this for a different hypothesis on the conservation of momentum front: it's not the taper of the whip.  When swung the entire whip is moving and has momentum, but as it rolls out the area behind the wave comes nearly  to a stop, passing most of it's momentum to the remaining length.  As roughly the same impulse is divided over a rapidly dwindling mass it approaches an asymptote and reaches an incredible speed at the end of the whip.

Once on a school trip to an Australian farm (in Perth, I believe?), a farmer and his son showed us how they cracked a whip by swinging it in a horizontal circle above the head then quickly changing the direction. I don't remember there being a popper too. The way they did it was they tied a knot in the whip itself a good ways up. According to them (or at least my childhood memory of their explanation), the knot travels down the whip as they are swinging, and when your change in direction is timed right as the knot gets to the end of the whip, you get the crack.

I have my doubts on the knot traveling down the whip part, as it was a long time ago, but I am a lot more confident about the tying knots into the whip instead of using a popper. So what Dr. Kanistras hypothesized that later tests appear to support is very likely common practice for some circles. Hope this anecdote might help in some ways!

I've cracked a lot of whips...  Seems to me that if you yank it back just before the whip fully extends it makes a louder crack.  I used to set milk cartons up and slice huge gouges in them.  My brother was standing about five feet out of range when a small piece, about 1-1/4" long broke off the tip and hit his arm.  It actually made a jagged cut in his arm that produced lots of blood.  I did not think at the time the whip was breaking the sound barrier — I thought it was simply snapping back against itself.  I think when you snap a wet towel, or piece of cloth, that is what's happening, and it can be every bit as loud as a bull whip.  It might be interesting to find out if a snapped towel is also breaking the sound barrier.  It needs to be a somewhat threadbare towel, though.  When I was a teenager I worked at a car wash, where there were plenty of worn-thin towels to snap like that.  We learned not to snap towels on Thursday — Thursday was police car day.

My experience with my whips has been that the loop is the key. Large and slow at the handle...as it moves down to the end of the whip it gets smaller and therefore speeds up enough to break the sound barrier. The knot and fray at the end helps to prevent further damage to the whip when the tip breaks the sound barrier. Would have to replace it every so often or the leather would get damaged. Without the loop, the speed would be to low to break the sound barrier. The reason ice skaters spin faster when they tighten their bodies in the spin. Thanks for the vid. Love the high speed work. Hello Dustin. I wanted to comment on something you said after 6:55 on the video. You said "most researchers say... it has to speed up..." I would disagree with this thought. If you have ever unrolled a spool of cord or any long material it travels faster as the roll gets smaller because the distance it needs to travel decreases as the roll gets smaller. In the instance of the whip not only does this apply but the mass is decreasing allowing for even higher speeds to be achieved. Somewhat like a multi stage rocket dropping lower stages to achieve higher speeds. So, the tip of the he whip is moving its fastest is when the last coil is unrolled and the remaining line is at its straightest and it all begins to move forward. Another way to say it is...(at this point the potential energy stored in the coil is released (no longer holding back) and then the tip nears its maximum forward velocity. As it travels forward and it reaches the maximum (breaking the sound barrier) is when the drag is at its lowest possible point.
I hope this makes sense. Thanks for doing such great videos.

A USB cable isn't tapered like a whip, so it shouldn't speed up like a whip due to conservation of momentum. On the other hand though, the length of the cable that is being dragged behind your hand is getting shorter and shorter, so the remaining amount is getting lighter and lighter as it gets closer to the end of the cable.

With the whip, wouldn't this mean that not only does the tapering cause the whip to speed up, but also the decreasing length that's being dragged by the wave is getting shorter, so its getting even more light as it gets closer to the snap? So there could be 2 separate causes of the increasing speed of the whip that combine to accelerate the whip to the speed of sound: tapering of the whip and remaining whip getting shorter, both of which decrease the remain amounts mass considerably at an ever increasing rate.

Kinda feel like a USB cable just taught me something about a whip, lol.

I wish people would get over this expression "breaking the sound barrier"  This expression conveys the wrong impression.  To break something is an event, a sonic boom is a process.  The impression I had as a kid was that the boom we would hear occurred just as the airplane accelerated past the speed of sound.  That would be an event.  Most people seem to have had a similar understanding of a sonic boom and I'm sure a lot of people still believe that.  Once I came to understand sonic booms I became somewhat confused and it took me years to figure out why people called it breaking the sound barrier.  The sound barrier was broken on Oct. 14, 1947 by Chuck Yeager and no longer exists. Prior to that time many people assumed that it was impossible for manned aircraft to operate faster than mach 1 for various reasons. Thus there was presumed to be a barrier at mach 1 which already claimed at least one life (Geoffrey de Havilland, Jr.)and a number of close calls. Subsequent developments in high speed aircraft design have made it possible to operate planes routinely at supersonic speeds with little concern. The use of the expression "breaking the sound barrier" by news media at the time along with the concept of a sonic boom became fixed in the public mind so that when one hears a sonic boom (a rare event today) one next hears the comment "that's a jet breaking the sound barrier". Nonsense, that boom (usually a distinct double boom) follows the aircraft as long as it continues at supersonic speed. Just where did it break the sound barrier? Where it first exceeded mach 1 or does it continue breaking (ripping?) the barrier all along it's path? If so it must be doing an awful lot of damage to that poor damned barrier. C'mon it's a plane flying at supersonic speed. Charlie broke the barrier long ago, It's broken, busted, gone, never really existed, leave it be.

OMG! 40 years ago a girlfriend convinced me to join her in an evening class where we made our own braided leather bullwhips from scratch. We started with tanned hides, sliced them, shaved them, dressed the strips to precise tapers, oiled then braided them. It took a team of two about 20 hours to make both whips. Then we got to learn various techniques, from gently capturing things (we learned to wrap our whip around a balloon without popping it), to wrapping hard enough to break things (my favorite was sidewalk chalk, which exploded).

But the best part was learning to crack our whips. We started by simply rolling the loop of the whip down onto the floor, where it would snap when the tip smacked down. Then we gradually added more energy, a truly small amount at a time, until it started to crack in the air. Large, graceful motions that finished with a crack. Then we learned quicker moves that brought the snap a little closer in, where we learned to place it where we wanted it. I envied the folks who were ambidextrous with their whips, because my right arm was getting ready to fall off.

We wanted to see if we could capture the motion of the whip by cracking it horizontally over sand, so a few of us took our whips to the beach and tried to crack the whip horizontally within an inch of the sand. Almost impossible to do, but once in a while we did notice a puff of sand happening well before the whip had reached full extension, from a part of the whip not in contact with the sand. If only...

Fast forward 25 years, and I was on the team making a camera that could take 100,000 frames per second (the Redlake HG-100K). When the third alpha unit became the first to work at full speed, we searched for targets that would both test the camera and thrill Marketing. Popping a balloon wasn't nearly fast enough. I thought back to my days with the bullwhip, and we immediately went out and bought a few. Despite dumping a zillion lumens into the field of view, nothing useful came of it. (Clearly, using Schlieren photography and capturing the shockwave is crucial.)

What we did wind up doing was pointing the camera at the HID bulb in an Epson video projector (torn from the ceiling of a conference room), where we captured the most amazing video of the arc wandering between the electrodes within the bulb envelope. We put a GIF of the sequence up on our website (this was before YouTube), which caused some small level of buzz online. The next morning we received phone calls from the Japanese executives of both Epson and Panasonic (the maker of the bulb). It turns out that arc wander was the primary factor limiting projector sharpness, so stabilizing the position of the arc was crucial to gaining any benefit from using higher-resolution LCDs. Two days later they were in our offices for a demo, and left an awesome pile of money behind when they departed with our very first beta unit. Their problem was that high-speed film limited the rate of innovation to one test run per day, with the film developed overnight: Our camera allowed them to do a dozen runs every day, leaping their R&D further ahead of the competition.

You may have noticed I mentioned we had to go out and buy some bullwhips. My treasured handmade bullwhip had disintegrated within a year of making it: Evidently, the tanning process used on the leather wasn't compatible with the oil we applied to it. It sure was fun while it lasted.

Now you two have got me wanting to make another one!

Made a "whip" myself when I was younger that functioned differently.
Used a fiberglass stick (~1 - 1,2 meters) and put a thin rope (5 mm diameter?) with a frayed end on it.
I swung that through the air rather slowly and then pulled the other direction very quickly.
What I believe happens is that I timed it that just before the first swing reached the tip of the whip, I quickly pulled it the other way, which accelerated the end very rapidly for a crack.
Instead of a loop traveling down the lenght of the whip, I believe mine never made a full loop but only half of it.
Think I also had a knot tied under the frayed end for extra mass.

I wonder if it would be more appropriate to consider the motion of the whip from the perspective of Conservation of ANGULAR Momentum (L) rather than Linear Momentum. If you look at the slow motion video, you can consider each point on the whip as a temporary axis of rotation for the mass of the whip beyond that point. Since L=Iω and I=∫mr², for L to stay constant, ω must explode in value since the rotational inertia (I) drops so violently as the rotational pulse moves down the whip. This exploding value for ω eventually causes the shock wave. Just a thought.

The whip tip accelerates after the shock wave for the same reason rocket exhaust accelerates after it passes through the throat of the rocket engine and become supersonic. Once the flow becomes supersonic there can be zero pressure(by definition) against the direction of the flow. The air particles are pushed into what, to them, behaves like a instantaneous vacuum as any particles in front of them are moving away from them at supersonic speed. In the case of the whip tip there is a small pocket of what is essentially vacuum just behind the shock wave and the whip gets pushed into this by air pressure.

Here's some food for thought for your research about the speeding end when the shockwave appears that you said you don't quite comprehend yet... When the wave is traveling THROUGH the whip, you have 'whip' mass ahead and behind the point where momentum is traveling through. That limits what the whip can do in terms of rotation/acceleration. But when all the gathered momentum reached the tip of the whip, there's only mass to one side of the whip (That will act as fulcrum), so to speak, meaning the other end is 'unrestricted' by further mass beyond to which to transfer momentum. This means all gathered momentum must be delivered to that final tip, which will pivot about the whip's turning point, accelerating very fast with normal acceleration (causing rotation) and the only way to disipate energy at that point is only drag, as the whip can't transfer momentum to the 'following section' because there are no more sections. So all the energy is finally turned into acceleration and the tip gets enough speed to break the sound barrier, which in turn, dissipates the quickly-gained energy. Hope this makes any sense or is useful. ;)

My kerbal space program intuition says the tip rockets forward because drag skyrockets during the transsonic range and then quickly falls off, while the tip is still at that point collecting momentum. Once it gets to about mach 1.2 the drag has dropped off by, if I'm reading this graph right, up to 30%. This is of course data from aerofoils and aircraft scale aerofoils, the tip being so small would probably have an even steeper decline in drag past mach 1.0, so all of the energy it gains after breaking the sound barrier is progressively more efficient at accelerating the tip. This would of course proportionally shorten the impulse which is why the tip suddenly jumps in speed but doesn't continue accelerating at the same rate. The 'catestrophic post mach acceleration' consumed all the available potential and now the tip is travelling too fast to accept more energy from the whip.

My hypothesis:

Kinetic energy is transmitted to the next segment of the whip, and since the mass of the segment is smaller every segment it goes forward this means that the speed increases each segment even above the friction and aerodynamic constrains to the point it goes over 330 m/s. Basically, the tip of the whip gets to move with it's tiny mass to a speed that makes it's EK the same as the user's arm plus full whip weight at the speed it has when cracked.

That EK moves like a wave and thus discards the already traversed weight, and the weight of the not-yet-traversed whip that is being unfolded keeps decreasing until it can no longed contain the EK imparted and it flings forward since the tips' momentum is superior to the momentum of the previous segment.

This Whip phenomenon could also be applied to slingshots, if the ammo is heavy enough to stay in the pouch before the "flick". Force is "multiplied", because segments of the whip transfer "leverage" or "moments" to sections of the whip after it.

Moment = Force X distance.

When the whip flicks, segment of whip transfers "moment" to the section after it, so that the moment or "leverage" at the tip of the whip is "tremendous"

The cross-sectional area of the "whip" is important, because if we assume that the force along the whip is uniform (this might not be correct), then the Pressure at the tip (smaller cross-section) will be larger than the pressure at the handle where the force is generated.

The conservation of momentum is right ofcourse, but I think a more useful way of looking at it is in terms of impedance matching. Basically you are trying to transfer energy from something heavy and slow to something light. The difference between this and a uniform length of rope is that you gradually change the impedance of the whip as the wave moves to the tip, so no reflections of the wave occurs. Then in the end, when the speed of the whip itself is high enough, you need to impedance match to the air. This is done by increasing drag while still impedance matching the whip itself. The solution is the special tip. It is nice and puffy so the drag is high but the weight is low. This transfers a lot of energy to the air, preventing a reflection from going back up the whip. I suspect that removing the last puffy bit decreases the crack, and increases the reflection of the wave. You can also make the whip long enough to eventually achieve an impedance match to the air, as drag increases super linearly with speed. But to keep the whip short it might be best to impedance match to the air as soon as the whip is super sonic. Compare to a length of rope. If you try to crack that, the wave will come back up the rope, and no part will be particularly fast ofcourse. An even more reflective experimental setup would be with rope where the end is secured to something. The wave would come right back and even feel violent. I also suspect that this gives a framework for optimizing whips from a theoretical perspective.

I think this has something to do with conservation of angular momentum: when the whiplash is performed, the string of the whip forms a ring which travels from the handle to the tip. This is somewhat similar to a wheel (with only a rim) traveling all the length of the whip to its very end.
This 'wheel' gets imparted a certain angular momentum from the arm and hand of the operator. As the angular momentum is conserved, the 'wheel' needs to spin ever faster, as the string of the whip gets thinner and the ring formed by this string gets smaller in diameter (the 'wheel' gets both smaller in diameter and lesser in mass).
When the 'wheel' reaches the end of the whip, something interesting is about to happen: at some point there is not enough string left to form a full wheel (due to the lack of a stabilizing counter weight the remaining outer part of the whip string provides in earlier stages). Instead, there is only an ever shrinking section of the ring which still needs to carry (almost) all of the angular momentum the 'wheel' had at the very start. When only a very short length of the string at the tip of the whip is left, this little piece of string needs to spin very violently around its own center to carry all that angular momentum. At that point the outer end of the string is dragged very quickly through the air (the inner end is kind of fixated by the rest of the whip), breaking the sound barrier and causing the shock wave seen in the video.
So, it's not only the decreasing diameter of the whip string, but also the 'collapse' of the ring formed by the string, which causes the crack.
The feathered end of the string only maximizes coupling of the motion of the string end to the surrounding air, IMHO, to make the shockwave stronger and thus the crack louder. I don't think it's necessary to break the sound barrier itself (as is demonstrated in your video).

I believe a similar thing happens when we throw a ball really hard.
.
We grip the ball with our fingers, curl up the elbow and take the whole hand behind our head. Initially, we start moving the entire hand forward, but the elbow is stopped suddenly due to dimensional restrictions of the upper arm bone. As soon as the elbow stops, the entire momentum is transferred to the arm and fingertips, and that part accelerates abruptly. It is at that point that we release the ball to get maximum speed. We don't release the ball at maximum extension of the hand. Would love to see an analysis of that!
Hand throw dynamics ~ Whip dynamics.

comment_text: Hi Destin. I actually have an idea about the effect you mentioned at the end, where the tip looks to be pulled along as it breaks the sound barrier. I don't want to spend forever talking about it here, in case this comment is simply never read. However, I think it has to do with the compressive force within the fabric of the whip. As the curve of the whip is approaching the speed of sound, it's experiencing more and more air pressure. This compresses the fabric of the whip behind it. The based on the structure and position of the whip, this compressive force is more or less opposite to the direction of the force of the air pressure. After the air pressure dissipates, this compressive force is released, propelling the curved portion of the whip forward. I don't think this explains everything, but I almost think of it as the opposite of what happens when you drop a slinky that you've dangled from a high place (another reference to Derek's videos). If you do read this, let me know what you think. -Chase

Its air resistance dudes. I am not an engineer, but I study a lot of geometry, what seems to be happening here, is that the tip of the whip accelerates, and the air that is trapped in the tip causes a drag that holds the tip of the whip, that causes the effect "tug of war" between the resistance of the air at the tip and the momentum of the whip, when the momentum "wins the contest", the tip is drawn with more force than was being pulled until the air drag starts acting (to compensate for the force of the momentum that was reduced in the dispute of the two forces), this generates an extra acceleration, that adds to the tension produced in the whip, and causes the tip of the whip to pass barrier of the sound. Probably different material whips produce different final velocities due to the elastic constants of each material and the tip size would also influence the amount of air trapped in the space between the wires of the tip, if I am right.
But still why ? I need more answers immediately!
